main event: An unidentified aerial object, resembling a circular, pulsating, and glowing body, was observed at high altitude over Simiutak, Greenland in 1953. Witnesses reported the object exhibiting erratic and rapid movements before disappearing from view after five minutes.
interesting points: The object was observed by a weather observer with three and a half years of experience tracking a weather balloon, and it was described as "silvery, metallic, circular shaped".
The object was noted to have collided with the weather balloon that was being tracked, disintegrating the balloon upon collision.
The object was observed to hover, make sudden erratic maneuvers, and then rapidly pick up speed, exhibiting shapes of both a triangular and disc-shaped object.
The winds aloft were observed to be at approximately 125 degrees at 16-20 knots, and the object was estimated to be traveling at a speed of 900 knots.

Trained observers described the object's flight characteristics as indicative of a 'guided' or 'controlled' object, and the incident was forwarded for analysis to the Air Technical Intelligence Center, Project Blue Book.
sighted object: unidentified aerial object resembling a circular, pulsating, and glowing body
witnesses: A/2c Richard A. Hill, other personnel of the 1st Rescue Squadron, and 5th Weather Detachment
photographs: no, the report does not include photographs
